sn5.10:1.2: Then the nun Vajira robed up in the morning and, taking her bowl and robe, entered Savatthi for alms.
sn5.10:1.3: She wandered for alms in Savatthi. After the meal, on her return from almsround, she went to the Dark Forest for the day’s meditation,
sn5.10:1.4: plunged deep into it, and sat at the root of a tree to meditate.
sn5.10:1.5: Then Mara the Wicked, wanting to make the nun Vajira feel fear, terror, and goosebumps, wanting to make her fall away from immersion, went up to her and addressed her in verse:
sn5.10:3.2: “Who’s speaking this verse, a human or a non-human?”
sn5.10:3.4: “This is Mara the Wicked, wanting to make me feel fear, terror, and goosebumps, wanting to make me fall away from immersion!”
sn5.10:3.5: Then Vajira, knowing that this was Mara the Wicked, replied to him in verse:
sn5.10:4.1: “Why do you believe there’s such a thing as a <j>‘sentient being’?
sn5.10:4.3: This is just a pile of conditions,
sn5.10:4.4: you won’t find a sentient being here.
sn5.10:5.3: So too, when the aggregates are present
sn5.10:5.4: ‘sentient being’ is the convention we use.
sn5.10:6.1: But it’s only suffering that comes to be,
sn5.10:6.3: Naught but suffering comes to be,
sn5.10:7.1: Then Mara the Wicked, thinking, “The nun Vajira knows me!” miserable and sad, vanished right there.
sn5.10:8.6: The Linked Discourses on Nuns are completed.
